;
;;Liz Truss
;

;Liz Truss 否认了她在任职期间破坏了英国经济的论点首相，虽然承认自己在第 10 号中犯了错误，但试图主要归咎于英格兰银行、媒体和公务员部门的“群体思维”。

;

;在周年纪念日前不久的一次演讲和问答中她的政府所谓的;迷你-预算;推动看似没有资金支持的 450 亿英镑减税计划，令市场感到恐慌，当被问及是否想向面临更高抵押贷款利率的家庭道歉时，特拉斯两次回避了这个问题。

;

;相反，她两次回避了这个问题。认为，主要问题在于英格兰银行等经济机构，它们允许人为的低利率持续太久，以及更广泛的“群体思维和共识意识”。

;

;她的;严重拖尾的演讲;，特拉斯明确表示她希望在保守党内重新提出她的经济论点，并确认她将参加下个月的保守党会议，在那里她将“发表更多言论”。

;

;她的明显复出引发了一些保守党议员的批评康纳·伯恩斯 (Conor Burns) 表示，特拉斯 (Truss) 对党的最佳贡献是“持续沉默”，而达米安·格林 (Damian Green) 则表示，他“很高兴她不为”今年的预算负责。

;

;被问及她 49 岁的经济记录是否特拉斯反驳道，“执政的几天损害了保守党的品牌”，并指责提问者附和反对派的观点。

;

;“我真的很想挑战‘经济崩溃’这句话，”她告诉研究所。政府活动。 “事实是，自从我离任以来，抵押贷款利率和金边债券利率都比迷你预算时更高。所以我认为你是在重复工党的说法。”

;

;英格兰银行一直在“向系统注入大量资金”，保持低利率，并允许“过度政府支出”，特拉斯争论道。

;

;“无论如何，利率都会上涨。我认为真正的失败是没有在很多年前告诉人们利率被人为压低。这就是问题所在，”她说。

;

;“我们给人们一种期望，廉价资金将永远持续下去。然后，当利率上升时，就会出现问题。”

;

;更广泛地说，特拉斯认为，面对媒体和政治格局，政客们拥有“所有责任，但不一定有权力”她说她本质上反对低税收、小州政府。

;

;当被问及为什么她没有让预算责任办公室 (OBR) 在迷你预算交付之前对其进行评估时，特拉斯表示 OBR没有被要求在 Covid 期间检查更大的支出承诺。

;

;“因此，我认为媒体组织因为没有 OBR 预测而选择以迷你预算为目标，这很有趣，但当“这与消费有关，”她说。

;

;“我确实认为这揭示了一种心态，那就是：消费是好的。他们对此总是很放松，但减税在某种程度上是一种反文化的行为。我认为这反映在媒体上。我认为这更广泛地反映在政体中。”

;

;特拉斯还指责 OBR 泄露了迷你预算中存在 700 亿英镑缺口的计算结果，试图破坏她的利益。 OBR 否认了这一点，称它只向财政部提供了任何预测。

;

;当被问及公务员部门试图阻止变革的例子时，特拉斯表示，这更多的是“警告和支持”的情况。覆盖”。

;
;

;;相关：;;《卫报》对利兹·特拉斯首相任期的看法：如果英国重复这个错误，那将是愚蠢的 |社论;

;
;

;她说：“对于任何与气候变化有关的事情，官员们都热情高涨，争相发表论文。如果是关于与卢旺达达成[移民]协议的事情，那么热情就会降低。”

;

;尽管特拉斯认为金融市场必然受到政治影响，但她承认她错误地判断了他们可能的反应：“如果我们如果我们知道市场的脆弱性，我们就会采取不同的做法。这类问题相当困难，因为很多问题，我做事的方式，基本上就是我的方式和我的性格。”

;

;被问到她是否接受许多保守党议员认为她的观点。特拉斯说，政府从根本上来说是无能的：“我不想做的就是指责。当然，这是一个非常困难的情况，很多人犯了很多错误。毫无疑问。”

; Mon, 18 Sep 2023 22:52:01 +0800 Chioma Nnadi to replace Edward Enninful as head of British Voguehttps://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2023/sep/18/chioma-nnadi-to-replace-edward-enninful-as-head-of-british-vogue
;;2023-09-18T12:10:27Z;
;
;;《Vogue》编辑内容新任主管 Chioma Nnadi，拍摄于纽约。
;

;由上周末伦敦时装周开始时，这已经是业界最保守的秘密了。

;

;但在围绕谁将取代 51 岁的英国《Vogue》杂志即将卸任编辑爱德华·恩尼弗 (Edward Enninful) 进行了数月的猜测之后，Condé纳斯特告诉《卫报》，出生于伦敦的记者 Chioma Nnadi 将于 10 月 9 日接任该职位。

;

;一旦上任，现任美国版网站编辑的 Nnadi 将被称为编辑内容主管，而不是主编。她也将成为第一位编辑这本传奇时尚杂志的黑人女性。

;

;“有压力吗？是的，压力肯定存在——这是《Vogue》，”Nnadi 在纽约的家中说道。

;

;“登上《Vogue》仍然有意义，它仍然具有权威。 [还有压力]因为爱德华。他开辟了新天地。它不仅仅是一本杂志的一部分，更是文化对话的一部分。”

;

;这一消息是在周末举办的时装秀之后发布的，而《Vogue World》（由该杂志策划的一项成功的艺术/时尚活动）在一定程度上让这些时装秀黯然失色。 ，这也被与会者称为“安娜·温图尔的弹性”。或许纳迪留在纽约是明智之举，以免煽动谣言。

;

;新的职位头衔并非无足轻重。 Nnadi 表示，她的重点将放在“数字化叙事”以及保持《Vogue》与读者的“互动”上，但这也是《Vogue》欧洲版明星编辑们的转变的一部分，他们曾经坐在前排，现在被全球负责人所取代。在康泰纳仕集团 2020 年进行全公司重组后。

;

;因此，Nnadi 很可能与 Wintour 一起工作，Wintour 将 Nnadi 描述为“亲爱的同事”，他将像关注时尚一样关注“音乐和文化” 。就 Nnadi 而言，她称赞 Wintour“将《Vogue》带入了未来”。

;

;在《Vogue World》结束后发表讲话时，她补充道：“在 Anna 的领导下工作，你会了解接下来会发生什么。我还没查过我的电子邮件，但她可能已经开始做下一件事了。”

;

;Nnadi 的母亲是瑞士裔德国人，母亲是一名护士，父亲是尼日利亚人，父亲在 20 世纪 60 年代来到英国学习，Nnadi 长大了在伦敦市中心的《标准晚报》任职之前，她曾在伦敦市中心为《Trace》和《The Fader》等独立杂志工作，她将这些归功于自己“斗志旺盛”的天性。

;

;2010 年，她搬到了纽约， Nnadi 目前在《Vogue》工作，负责美国网站的运营、播客的共同主持，并且是该杂志的明星作家之一，也是 Wintour 口号“所有平台 - 任何时候”的活生生体现。

;

;她说，她希望人们将她和恩尼弗尔进行比较，但对她们的差异进行了评估：“作为一名黑人女性，也是一名混血女性，我看待世界的方式也是我看待世界的方式——通过一个镜头，受到我的背景、居住地、父母来自不同文化以及必须在这些文化之间流动的影响。

;

;“事情发生了很大变化。当我开始工作时，大楼里还有另一个黑人工作，我们都上同一所大学。那地方和现在不一样。显然，多样性和包容性问题应该始终提上议程，但现在感觉更像是一场公开对话，对我来说这感觉像是进步。”她说。

; ;

;Nnadi 是一名编辑和作家，而 Enninful 则从事造型工作。她说她认识到《Vogue》首先是一本时尚杂志，但她觉得“无论你是设计还是写作，冲动都是一样的。爱德华有这种本能，尽管他的背景与我不同。但问题始终是，我们如何捕捉时代精神。重要的是要思考谁在讲故事，以及我们在讲谁的故事。”

;

;Enninful 在 2024 年 3 月刊登上报摊后宣布他将离开《Vogue》。他作为第一位男性编辑和第一位黑人编辑成功但短暂地任职了六年，在此期间，他因拍摄各种肤色、体型和背景的人物而受到称赞，他的离职令人震惊。 Enninful 计划继续留在 Condé Nast 担任顾问，并将在不久的将来与 Nnadi 合作。 “由于我们在全球的工作方式，[英国办事处]; ;已经是我的同事了，”她说，并补充说他们已经每周举行三次会议。

;

;Nnadi 非常精通针对该杂志的批评，尤其是其经常脱离时尚的价格点。 “当我开始在《Vogue》工作时，我的目标是拥有最新的新事物，”她说。 “现在，档案时尚也同样重要。我从小到大每个周末都会去波托贝洛路寻找复古服装。那是在这件事变得超级酷之前。”这个恶魔会穿Vintage吗？ “当我在伦敦时，我总是会去 Rellik，并在周五去 Ladbroke Grove，所以现在我衣柜里的大部分都是转售和复古的”，她说。 “当然，随着我的进步，我也能买得起新东西了，”她说。不过，她最珍贵的财产之一是一件爱德华时代的裙子。

;

;纳迪说，她仍在伦敦寻找房子，并计划与家人住在一起，直到找到住处。尽管在国外呆了十多年，她说她本质上仍然是伦敦人，尽管自从发现她的朋友搬到了东伦敦后，她承认“自从我来到这里以来，酷的轴心确实发生了变化。这是一次回家，但显然也是一个学习的时刻。”

; Mon, 18 Sep 2023 21:22:01 +0800 Rolling Stone founder Jann Wenner apologizes for disparaging Black and female artistshttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/sep/18/jann-wenner-rolling-stone-apology-black-female-artists-interview
;;2023-09-18T13:05:41Z;
;
;;Jann Wenner 出席 2017 年摇滚名人堂入职仪式。
;

;Jann Wenner滚石乐队创始人兼摇滚名人堂联合创始人，已为;他的言论;贬低黑人和女性艺术家，因为他们在智力上不如白人同行。

; <这位 77 岁的老人在周五发表的采访中发表的声明 ;《纽约时报》;，他解释了为什么他在一本汇编他采访的书中只收录了白人摇滚表演者，他称之为“摇滚哲学家”——导致一致投票将温纳从名单中除名。温纳在他的《大师》一书中接受的采访提供了波诺、鲍勃·迪伦、杰里·加西亚、米克·贾格尔、约翰·列侬、布鲁斯·斯普林斯汀和皮特·汤森德等音乐家的观点，他们都是名人堂成员。白人男性。

;

;他告诉《泰晤士报》，这次选择“不是故意的选择……就女性而言，她们在这个智力水平上没有一个人能表达得足够清楚”。

;

;他还表示，当时的黑人表演者并不“处于;时代精神;”。

;

; “黑人艺术家——你知道，史蒂夫·旺德，天才，对吧？我想当你使用像‘大师’这样广泛的词时，错误就在于使用这个词，”温纳说。 “也许是马文·盖伊，或者柯蒂斯·梅菲尔德？我的意思是，他们只是没有在那个层面上表达清楚。”

;

;温纳试图通过周末的一系列道歉来消除由此造成的损害，其中包括向出版商利特尔布朗公司道歉，他在道歉中表示：说：“我对这些言论表示衷心的歉意。”

;

;他补充说，他在书中选择的采访内容“并不反映我对无数图腾般的、改变世界的艺术家的欣赏和钦佩，他们的音乐和想法只要我活着，我就会尊敬、庆祝和宣传。我完全理解错误用词的煽动性，并深表歉意并接受后果”。

;

;温纳于 1967 年创立《滚石》杂志，并担任其编辑或编辑总监直至 2019 年。在 1983 年帮助创办名人堂后，于 2004 年以非表演者身份跻身名人堂。

;

;但是，该组织经常被视为不符合白摇滚标准的音乐家的封闭商店，并且其规模较小。为行业友好的音乐家和行业套装举办的超时尚庆祝活动。

;

;自 2020 年以来，该音乐厅的主席约翰·赛克斯 (John Sykes) 试图改变这一现状。 “摇滚乐是摇滚乐的一部分，但摇滚乐从来都不是一种声音。”;他最近告诉公告牌。 ;“这是 R&B、福音音乐和乡村音乐的混合体。”

;

;今年的入选者包括 Missy Elliott、The Spinners、Willie Nelson 和 Rage Against the Machine。 “我确实没有改变规则。我回去跟踪他们。”赛克斯说道。

;

;赛克斯告诉该刊物，2019 年之前，大约 14% 到 15% 的入选者是女性。过去五年，这一比例几乎达到了 25%。赛克斯说：“我们还没有做到这一点，但我们看到入选者阶层不仅在声音方面而且在风格方面都在发展。”

;

;但温纳的评论留下了污点。乔·哈根 (Joe Hagan) – 撰写了《粘手指》(Sticky Fingers)，这是一本批评但经过授权的温纳传记，;在作者和他的主题之间造成了痛苦的争吵; – ;在 X 上发表了评论;由女权主义评论家艾伦·威利斯（Ellen Willis）撰写，她拒绝为《滚石》杂志撰稿，称其“恶毒地反女性”。

;

;《滚石》“习惯性地将女性称为小鸡，并将我们视为小鸡，即可互换的可爱的他妈的机器，”威利斯的评论中写道。威利斯在 1970 年撰文，还表示温纳对革命政治的偏见助长了对妇女的压迫。

;

;“对我来说，当一群势利的中上阶层白人男性开始告诉我政治并不重要时就其所在而言，这只是为了捍卫他们的特权。他们想要的是更多的面包和马戏团，”她写道。

;

;在《泰晤士报》采访中，温纳似乎承认他将面临强烈反对。他说：“出于公共关系的考虑，也许我应该去找一位黑人和一位女性艺术家，将他们纳入其中，但这些艺术家不符合同样的历史标准，只是为了避免这种批评。”

;

;五名被关押在伊朗的美国囚犯（其中一些被关押了近十年）已乘飞机离开该国前往卡塔尔，这是有争议的囚犯交换的一部分，涉及伊朗解冻。 .com/international/lists/tag/us-news/biden-administration">;拜登管理; 60亿美元（48亿英镑）的伊朗石油资金。

;

;德黑兰和华盛顿已同意每人交换五名囚犯，包括;环境保护主义者莫拉德·塔赫巴兹;，英裔美国公民。

;

;在一项耗时数月精心策划的外交协议中，五名美国人被从酒店带走他们在德黑兰搭乘飞往卡塔尔的飞机，这是他们飞往华盛顿的旅程的第一阶段。

;

;卡塔尔一直充当该交易的调解人，从伊朗人的电子转账开始现金存入卡塔尔和瑞士的银行账户。现金转账完成后，囚犯才被允许登机。除塔赫巴兹外，只有另外两名美国人的身份被公开。

;

;美国共和党参议员和一些前伊朗政治犯已指控;乔·拜登;达成一项协议，该协议只会鼓励伊朗继续将劫持人质作为其外交武器的核心部分。美国国务院表示，释放的资金是欠伊朗的石油资金，并在 2018 年美国退出伊朗核协议时被特朗普政府冻结。

;

;目前尚不清楚该协议是否会导致实现更广泛的外交突破，或者采取新的、不太雄心勃勃的路线来限制伊朗的民用核计划，其中德黑兰同意降低其高浓缩铀库存。

;
;

;;相关：;;英国、法国和德国拒绝根据核协议解除对伊朗的制裁;

;
;

;上周，包括英国在内的三个欧洲国家被指控;伊朗;正在建设不可能用于民用目的的高浓缩铀库存。

;

;美国表示，卡塔尔将确保解冻资金仅用于购买不受制裁的商品，主要是食品、农产品和药品。然而，批评者表示，监管是不可能的。

;

;最近，当美国国务院同意一项豁免，以方便将现金从韩国银行转入瑞士和瑞士的账户时，互换之路到达了一个转折点。多哈。

;

;

;

;“在德尔纳灾难发生后，我们现在必须认真解决利比亚其他水坝的问题，以解决利比亚其他水坝问题。”当地政治分析家阿里·阿布·扎伊德 (Ali Abu Zeid) 表示：“防止我们无法承受的后果。”

;

;其中包括 Al-Khums 山谷大坝，他说该大坝对 Al-Khums 市构成了真正的威胁Madjannin 谷大坝威胁着的黎波里南部的大型人口中心。

;

; <在德尔纳找到幸存者的希望与日俱增。专业团队正在不知疲倦地工作，当地官员警告称，可能需要将城市全部或部分疏散到 ;防止疾病传播;。 The sea continues to wash up more bodies every day.

; Mon, 18 Sep 2023 19:52:01 +0800 EU states expressed ‘incomprehension’ at Tunisia migration pact, says Borrellhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/18/eu-states-expressed-incomprehension-at-tunisia-migration-pact-says-borrell
;;2023-09-18T11:39:12Z;
;
;;Josep Borrell and Ursula von der Leyen at a European Council summit in Brussels in June
;

;EU member states expressed “incomprehension” when the European Commission president, Ursula von der Leyen, rushed into a ;migration pact with Tunisia;, it has been revealed.

;

;The concerns were raised in July both verbally and in writing, the EU's chief diplomat responsible for foreign affairs, Josep Borrell, wrote in a letter dated 7 September that has been seen by the Guardian.

;

;“As you know … in July, several member states expressed their incomprehension regarding the commission's unilateral action on the conclusion of this [memorandum of understanding] and concerns about some of its contents,” Borrell wrote in a letter to; ;Olivér Várhelyi, the European commissioner for neighbouring countries. “After the foreign affairs council meeting on 20 July some member states referred these concerns by written procedure to you.”

;

;The pact, signed with Tunisia in July by Von der Leyen, the Italian prime minister, Giorgia Meloni, and the Dutch prime minister, Mark Rutte, was aimed at stemming migration to Europe from Tunisia, which had become one of the most popular routes for people smugglers working in Africa after Libya became too dangerous even for organised criminal gangs.

;

;The letter also says that foreign affairs ministers had “observed the proper steps of the adoption procedure had not been followed” by the commission and that therefore the memorandum of understanding could not be “considered a valid template for future agreements”.

;

;It is not clear why Borrell wrote the letter two months after the deal was signed, but it appears to be an attempt to ensure that a similar deal is not repeated with other north African countries without proper consultation with member states. His letter recalls a previous high-profile clash between the commission and member states in relation to a rushed deal with Switzerland on another matter.

;

;In a broadside against Meloni and Rutte, Borrell wrote that “the participation in the negotiation and the signing ceremony of a limited number of EU heads of government does not make up for the institutional balance between the council and the commission”.

;

;The letter was written days before Sunday's ;visit by Von der Leyen and Meloni to Lampedusa;, a small island off the coast of Sicily that the Italian leader says has been overwhelmed by arrivals from Tunisia.

;

;The deal was aimed at combatting the criminal gangs running the smuggling operations and strengthening border controls and search and rescue operations. However, since it was signed the number of people crossing from Tunisia to Italy has gone up almost 70%, though experts have pointed out that poor weather in May meant a rise was inevitable in June and July when the seas were calmer.

;

;The pact was driven by Meloni, but, apart from the objection from Borrell, appeared to be backed by the rest of Europe, where migration is seen as a critical issue in elections, particularly those looming in Poland and the Netherlands.

;

;On Wednesday a group of MEPs from the European parliament ;were refused entry to Tunisia;, raising questions about the partnership and further doubts over the willingness of the Tunisian president, Kais Saied, to address concerns about a reduction in human rights and the independence of the judiciary on his watch.

;

;The £105m deal was also criticised last week by the charity Médecins Sans Frontières, which said it would make the bloc “directly complicit in the ongoing abuse and deaths of people trapped in the country”.

;

;No money has yet changed hands in Tunisia but the EU said over the weekend efforts to help police the boarder were under way including the refitting of 17 vessels for the Tunisian authorities for search and rescue operations.

; Mon, 18 Sep 2023 19:52:01 +0800 London facing 45C days ‘in foreseeable future’, mayor Sadiq Khan warnshttps://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/sep/18/london-facing-45c-days-in-foreseeable-future-mayor-sadiq-khan-warns

;

;London faces the “incredibly worrying” prospect of enduring days that hit 45C (113F) due to the worsening climate crisis, its mayor, Sadiq Khan, told the Guardian at a climate summit in New York where governments have gathered to discuss how to best cope with searing temperatures.

;

;Khan said an interim independent climate resilience report for London has found the capital could experience multiple 45C days “in the foreseeable future”, potentially buckling various basic functions of the city. “It means the Underground is not fit for purpose, some of the homes are too hot in the daytime, care homes and schools too,” Khan said.

;

;“It means we have to adapt for those temperatures now. It's now time for those who are delaying action to wake up and smell the coffee because this is happening now. It's now and it's happening to us.”

;
;

;;Related: ;;'Green policies are the new Brexit': a day on the frontline of London's clean air zone;

;
;

;The London mayor said he had ensured the planting of more shading trees and the installation of air conditioning on buses but that more government support was needed to help cities adapt to the climate crisis, criticising the UK's Conservative government for not providing a green stimulus akin to the ;US's Inflation Reduction Act ;to help retrofit buildings and spur jobs in renewable energy.

;

;“We are learning expertise from other cities but we can't pretend we aren't behind because the UK has been slow catching up,” Khan said from New York, ahead of the annual UN general assembly and a special climate summit this week.

;

;“We have to throw everything at this. We've had very little support from the government. The fact the prime minister [Rishi Sunak] isn't coming to the UN general assembly and may not go to Cop28 speaks volumes.”

;

;London's climate review ;was launched in June;, nearly a year after the UK capital experienced an extraordinary, record-breaking heatwave. Temperatures breached 40C (104F) in London for the first time on record in July last year, causing schools to close, hospital operations to be cancelled and for the London fire brigade to have its busiest day since the second world war as it fought numerous blazes, including wildfires at the city's outskirts.

;

;Temperatures of 40C were previously almost unthinkable for the temperate climes of the UK, with Professor Hannah Cloke, at the University of Reading, ;saying at the time of the heatwave;: “The all-time temperature record for the UK has not just been broken, it has been absolutely obliterated. Even as a climate scientist who studies this stuff, this is scary.”

;

;But the reality of the worsening climate crisis will heighten the risk of even hotter temperatures in the future. London faces the distinct possibility of enduring withering temperatures of 45C, along with other hazards such as flooding, as the world continues to heat up, according to Emma Howard Boyd, the chair of the climate review and former chair of the UK Environment Agency.

;

;“Forty-five degrees Celsius is something we could see in the coming years,” Howard Boyd, who will release a full set of recommendations at the end of the review in December, told the Guardian.

; ;

;“Not many people really thought we'd experience 40C until we did last year, so we need this review to understand how we keep the city thriving in terms of people's health and working environment even under these higher temperatures. Everything we're hearing from scientists is that Europe is heating up quicker than anywhere else.”

;

;Khan is in New York at the start of a week-long ;Climate Week; summit involving numerous businesses, governments and environmental groups that runs alongside the UN general assembly which will, on Wednesday, include ;a gathering; of more than 100 national governments aimed at heightening global ambition to cut emissions. The UN ;has warned the world; is well off track to meet goals that would avert disastrous climate change.

;

;Meanwhile, New York City itself is bringing in the first congestion charge for cars in any US city next year, a move that proponents say will help cut emissions, help tackle deadly air pollution and reduce the severe traffic jams that ;cost; New Yorkers 117 hours of their time, on average, each year.

;

;The new congestion pricing scheme will apply to cars in Manhattan below 60;th; street and ;could cost; anything up to $23 a trip, with funding going towards New York's beleaguered Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) to help upgrade its heavily used but fraying network of subway trains and buses. Technology to scan cars as they enter the zone is ;already being put in place;.

;

;The plan was approved by the federal government in June but has faced staunch opposition from some politicians, Uber drivers and business owners who claim it is unfair on those who commute by car. “We have to put our foot down to protect New Jerseyans,” Phil Murphy, the governor of the neighbouring state of New Jersey, which is ;suing to stop the plan;, said in July. “We're not going to allow this poorly designed proposal to be fast-tracked.”

;

;The controversy has some echoes for Khan, who presides over a city that has had congestion pricing since 2003 and recently provoked ire among some residents by expanding its Ultra Low Emission Zone (or Ulez) to the whole of Greater London, forcing people to pay a daily fee if they drive a car that doesn't comply with pollution standards.

;

;The backlash to the Ulez expansion has been ;widely blamed; for Labour failing to take Boris Johnson's former seat of Uxbridge in July, placing pressure on Khan to scale back the scheme.

;

;“It's simply not sustainable for in London 10 million people to drive around in cars [or] in New York for 9 million people to drive around in cars,” Khan said. “You've got to listen to genuine concerns people have and try to address them, at the same time be cognisant that there's a vocal minority backed by vested interests that are opposing stuff.

;

;“Cities have got to incentivise policies that encourage people to use alternatives to the car. I understand the reasons New York wants to do this, what they will need to do is make sure they have alternatives in place.”

;

;The MTA, which is overseeing congestion pricing in New York, has said it looked to London, as well as other cities that charge drivers in urban cores such as Stockholm and Milan, in the design of its own congestion price. “Congestion is bad and it's got a lot worse in the last 10 to 15 years,” ;said; Juliette Michaelson, a special adviser to the MTA. “We know the best way to manage congestion is through pricing, the effect is immediate and sustained over time.”

;

;Despite the opposition to the initiative, public transport advocates believe New York is finally about to fulfil the demands of activists who have, for decades, pushed for congestion pricing. “It's been a long time coming,” said Philip Miatkowski, senior director of research and policy at Transportation Alternatives. “This is a once-in-a-generation opportunity to make New York City better. We really want this to be a success, like in London, so it can be copied in other cities in the US.”

;

;Male Ukrainian nationals of conscription age are allowed to cross the border only if they are financially supporting three or more children under the age of 18, are single fathers of children under 18, or have children or are guardians of children with disabilities.
